DPR.DPRN1_L1: The regulations of the Dental Council concerning professional ethics and patient rights in dentistry, issued in 1998.
DPR.DPRN1_L2: The patient rights declaration jointly issued by the Medical Professional Council and the Ministry of Public Health on April 16, 1998, to certify the patient's rights to medical services. Although it is not legally binding, the Dental Council endorses the patient rights declaration. Therefore, to ensure that dental professionals are aware and comply with patient rights, it is advisable to give legal effect to the patient rights declaration, which will protect patients receiving dental services.
DPR.DPRN1_L3: Based on the authority in Sections 8 (4), 9 (7), and 23 (4) (ฏ) (ฌ) with the consent of the special executive committee under Section 27 of the Dental Professions Act of 1994, and the resolution of the Dental Professional Council in the /2550 meeting held in 2007, the Dental Professional Council issued regulations on professional ethics and patient rights in dentistry.
DPR.DPRN1_L4: The provisions in these regulations are considered the professional ethics of dental professionals according to the Dental Council's regulations concerning professional ethics in dentistry. The term 'patient' refers to individuals receiving dental services.
DPR.DPRN1_L5: The text in Section 15 of the Dental Council's regulations concerning professional ethics in dentistry, issued in 1995, is revoked.
DPR.DPRN1_L6: Dental professionals must acknowledge that every patient has a fundamental right to receive health services as prescribed in the Constitution.
DPR.DPRN1_L7: Dental professionals must provide sufficient and clear information to allow patients to make informed decisions about their dental care, except in cases of emergency or necessity.
DPR.DPRN1_L8: Dental professionals must provide immediate assistance to patients in life-threatening conditions without considering whether the patient has requested assistance or not.
DPR.DPRN1_L9: When requested, dental professionals must disclose their name, surname, and professional category to the patient.
DPR.DPRN1_L10: Dental professionals must be willing to listen to the opinions of patients regarding dental or other health professionals, even if they are not the service providers, and patients have the right to request a change of service provider or healthcare facility.
DPR.DPRN1_L11: Dental professionals must provide complete information and explanations to allow patients to make decisions about participating or withdrawing from dental research experiments.
DPR.DPRN1_L12: Dental professionals must provide patients with information about their specific medical treatment recorded in the medical records upon patient request. However, this information must not violate the privacy rights of other individuals.
DPR.DPRN1_L13: Dental professionals must grant the right to parents, guardians, or representatives to exercise the rights on behalf of patients who are children under the age of eighteen or individuals with physical or mental disabilities who cannot exercise their rights themselves. This regulation becomes effective from the day following its announcement in the Royal Gazette.
DPR.DPRN2_L1: 'Rights' is a very popular term in our recent political events in our country. Whether it is the yellow shirt or the red shirt group, they often claim that their rallies are their rights under the Thai Constitution of 2007, Article 63, which states that individuals have the right to peaceful assembly without weapons, which is a matter of freedom of assembly recognized by the state. Now, when it comes to patients, what rights do they have? Are there laws that protect their rights?
DPR.DPRN2_L2: There are two parts to patients' rights. The first part is the inherent rights that patients have when they are in a patient status, such as the right to know who will be treating them, what treatment methods will be used, and what will be used for treatment. These rights arise naturally and do not necessarily need to be legislated. They are matters that can always be inquired about.
DPR.DPRN2_L3: The other part of patients' rights is the rights established by legislation to protect patients, such as the Thai Constitution of 2007, Article 51, which states that individuals have the right to receive appropriate and standardized health services, and indigent persons have the right to receive medical care from state health facilities without charge. Individuals have the right to receive health services from the state that must be comprehensive and efficient, among others. Therefore,
DPR.DPRN2_L4: in order for patients to be aware of their rights, whether they are natural rights or rights established by law, and to ensure a good relationship between patients and healthcare professionals based on mutual understanding and trust, professional healthcare organizations, such as the Medical Council, Nursing Council, Pharmacy Council, Dental Council, and the Committee on the Control of the Practice of Healing Arts, are aware of the importance of these patient rights. They have collectively compiled and published a Patient Rights Declaration and required all healthcare facilities, whether government or private, to display and inform the public about their rights. The Patient Rights Declaration consists of 10 points, some people may have seen it but never read it, and some may have skimmed through it without much interest. Therefore, I would like to encourage everyone that when you visit any healthcare facility, if you have the time, try to read the Patient Rights Declaration in detail. You will discover that these are rights that we should all be aware of and have. To explain the patient's rights according to the aforementioned declaration, I would like to present them as follows:
DPR.DPRN2_L5: 1. It is the right of everyone to receive healthcare services as stipulated in the Constitution of the Kingdom of Thailand, which currently is the 2007 Constitution. Article 51 of the Constitution mandates that everyone has the right to receive appropriate and standardized healthcare services that are universally accessible and efficient.
DPR.DPRN2_L6: 2. The right to receive services without discrimination based on factors such as social status, race, nationality, religion, society, political ideology, gender, age, or physical appearance. Regardless of political affiliation, wearing a red or yellow shirt, being rich or poor, young or old, handsome or not, or beautiful or not, everyone has the right to receive services on an equal basis. However, in reality, there are sometimes issues, especially regarding socioeconomic status. There are often complaints that the poor receive different treatment compared to the rich.
DPR.DPRN2_L7: 3. The right to access sufficient information, such as knowing what disease one has, the treatment options available, how the treatment will be carried out, the chances of recovery, and the cost of treatment. Individuals have the right to ask questions and, in some cases where multiple treatment options are available, the right to choose a preferred method or even refuse treatment. This is necessary because in some cases, with a high number of patients and limited time, healthcare providers may not be able to provide detailed explanations, or patients may not understand or remember the information provided, leading to ongoing issues in these areas.
DPR.DPRN2_L8: 4. When facing a life-threatening emergency, individuals have the right to receive immediate necessary assistance without having to request it. This includes situations where individuals arrive at a hospital in an emergency, and doctors are obligated to provide urgent treatment without first inquiring about the patient's ability to pay for the treatment. It is unfortunate that such incidents occur where patients are denied treatment because doctors first inquire about payment before providing emergency care.
DPR.DPRN2_L9: 5. The right to know the names of healthcare providers. For example, when entering an examination room, patients have the right to ask for the names of the doctors or nurses who will be providing the care (although in most cases, the names of the doctors are displayed outside the room).
DPR.DPRN2_L10: 6. The right to seek opinions from other healthcare professionals who are not directly involved in one's care and the right to request a change of healthcare provider or facility. For instance, if a patient has doubts about a diagnosis or treatment, they have the right to seek a second opinion from another doctor. If a patient is not satisfied with the attitude or behavior of a particular doctor, they have the right to request a change of doctor. Similarly, if it is inconvenient to receive treatment at a particular hospital, patients have the right to change hospitals.
DPR.DPRN2_L11: 7. The right to privacy, which is an ethical principle stipulated in the professional regulations of healthcare professionals to be strictly adhered to, unless consent is obtained from the patient or it is a legal obligation.
DPR.DPRN2_L12: 8. The right to receive comprehensive information to make an informed decision about participating in or withdrawing from experimentation. In some cases, doctors may conduct research, experimental treatments, or new technologies on patients. As a patient, you have the right to be informed about the details of the experiment, its benefits, risks, duration, or other relevant information in order to make a decision about participating or withdrawing from the experiment.
DPR.DPRN2_L13: 9. The right to access personal medical treatment information recorded in the medical records upon request. However, this should not violate the privacy rights of other individuals. This means that as a patient, you have the right to request personal treatment information recorded in your medical records, but not the medical records themselves, as medical records are the property of the healthcare facility.
DPR.DPRN2_L14: 10. Parents, legal guardians, or persons of sound judgment may exercise the rights on behalf of patients who are children under the age of eighteen or individuals with physical or mental disabilities who are unable to exercise their rights themselves. This right is already established in commercial and civil laws, but it is reiterated in the Patient Rights Declaration to emphasize its existing nature.
DPR.DPRN2_L15: All of the aforementioned are the ten rights stated in the declaration. The rights that often encounter issues are usually the third point, which concerns receiving sufficient information about the patient's condition, treatment procedures, treatment outcomes, side effects, or other relevant details that the patient should be aware of. Misunderstandings regarding this point often lead to complaints, lawsuits, or legal cases. Another point that frequently encounters practical issues is the ninth right, where patients may want to request information about their treatment for further treatment or other purposes. Patients often desire a copy of their medical records. However, healthcare facilities often provide a certificate of treatment that summarizes the details of the treatment. Although the certificate should be sufficient as a document for further treatment, if patients insist on requesting a copy of their medical records, they have the right to do so, and healthcare facilities must comply. However, healthcare facilities may feel that they could be subject to complaints or lawsuits if they provide copies, leading to a deterioration of the relationship between patients and healthcare professionals. As for X-ray films or dental impressions, these are additional evidence related to medical treatment according to the Hospital Act of 1998, which healthcare facilities must retain for at least five years according to the law. However, if patients genuinely want copies, they can proceed by officially requesting the healthcare facility and signing their names, similar to the process in government hospitals. For private healthcare facilities, since X-ray films and dental impressions are additional evidence related to medical treatment under the Hospital Act, healthcare facilities are required to retain them. If patients insist on requesting copies, they can proceed by submitting an official letter to the healthcare facility and signing their names, similar to the process in government hospitals. Ultimately, these measures aim to maximize the benefits for the patients.

DS.DSN1_L1: The schedule of healthcare service fees for reimbursement of medical expenses in government hospitals has been prepared by the Ministry of Finance's Comptroller General's Department, based on data provided by the Ministry of Public Health.
DS.DSN1_L2: It is used to determine the service fees for healthcare facilities under the Ministry of Public Health. It is based on the year 2004 as a reference because it provides comprehensive coverage. Representatives from various affiliated hospitals, including hospitals affiliated with the Medical School Division, Ministry of Defense, and Ministry of Public Health, were invited to participate in the process.
DS.DSN1_L3: Dental service fees refer to the fees for dental treatments for specific procedures or conditions. The fees cover the cost of services, instruments, basic medications, and disposable materials.
DS.DSN1_L4: It should be noted that the reimbursable dental services are those related to medical treatments for illness or accidents, such as tooth extraction, filling, scaling, and emergency orthodontic treatments (supported by a certification letter as evidence for reimbursement). Cosmetic procedures, such as teeth whitening, dental implants, crowns, and preventive procedures (e.g., dental sealants, fluoride application), are not reimbursable.
DS.DSN1_L5: Please note that expenses for orthodontic treatments, dentures, dental implants, and preventive procedures (such as dental sealants and fluoride application) are not eligible for reimbursement.
